pli-tv-kd14:4.3.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.2: “Monks, the Sangha should appoint Dabba the Mallian as the assigner of dwellings and the designator of meals.
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.3: And he should be appointed like this.
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.5: A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.6: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.7: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, it should appoint Venerable Dabba the Mallian as the assigner of dwellings and the designator of meals.
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.9: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.

pli-tv-kd14:4.3.11: Any monk who approves of appointing Venerable Dabba as the assigner of dwellings and the designator of meals should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd14:4.3.12: Any monk who doesn’t approve should speak up.

pli-tv-kd14:4.3.14: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I’ll remember it thus.’”

pli-tv-kd14:12.4.3: he’s ignorant, incompetent, often committing offenses, lacking in boundaries;
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.4: he’s constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.6: When a monk has another three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of further penalty against him:
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.7: he has failed in the higher morality; he has failed in conduct; he has failed in view.
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.9: When a monk has another three qualities, the Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of further penalty against him:
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.10: he disparages the Buddha; he disparages the Teaching; he disparages the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.12: The Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of further penalty against three kinds of monks:
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.14: and creators of legal issues in the Sangha;
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.15: those who are ignorant, incompetent, often committing offenses, lacking in boundaries;
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.16: those who are constantly and improperly socializing with householders.
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.18: The Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of further penalty against another three kinds of monks:
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.19: those who've failed in the higher morality; those who've failed in the higher conduct; those who've failed in view.
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.21: The Sangha may, if it wishes, do a procedure of further penalty against another three kinds of monks:
pli-tv-kd14:12.4.22: those who disparage the Buddha; those who disparage the Teaching; those who disparage the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.1: “A monk who's had a legal procedure of further penalty done against himself should conduct himself properly.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.3: He shouldn’t give the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.5: He shouldn’t have a novice monk attend on him.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.6: He shouldn’t accept being appointed as an instructor of the nuns.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.1: Even if appointed, he shouldn’t instruct the nuns.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.2: He shouldn’t commit the same offense as the offense for which the Sangha did the procedure of further penalty against him.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.3: He shouldn’t commit an offense similar to the offense for which the Sangha did the procedure of further penalty against him.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.4: He shouldn’t commit an offense worse than the offense for which the Sangha did the procedure of further penalty against him.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.6: He shouldn’t criticize those who did the procedure.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.7: He shouldn’t cancel the observance-day procedure of a regular monk.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.8: He shouldn’t cancel the invitation of a regular monk.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.9: He shouldn’t direct a regular monk.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.10: He shouldn’t give instructions to a regular monk.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.11: He shouldn’t ask a regular monk for permission to accuse him of an offense.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.12: He shouldn’t accuse a regular monk of an offense.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.7.13: He shouldn’t remind a regular monk of an offense.
pli-tv-kd14:12.5.8: He shouldn’t associate inappropriately with other monks.”

pli-tv-kd14:13.1.0: 7. Covering over as if with grass
pli-tv-kd14:13.1.1: At one time, while the monks were arguing and disputing, they did and said many things unworthy of monastics.
pli-tv-kd14:13.1.4: “If we deal with one another for these offenses, this legal issue might lead to harshness, nastiness, and schism.
pli-tv-kd14:13.1.5: So what should we do now?”
pli-tv-kd14:13.1.7: “It may be, monks, that monks who are arguing and disputing do and say many things unworthy of monastics.
pli-tv-kd14:13.1.8: If they consider this and think,
pli-tv-kd14:13.1.10: ‘If we deal with one another for these offenses, this legal issue might lead to harshness, nastiness, and schism,’ then I allow you to resolve that legal issue by covering over as if with grass.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.1: And it should be resolved like this.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.2: Everyone should gather in one place. A competent and capable monk should then inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.3: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.4: While we were arguing and disputing, we did and said many things unworthy of monastics.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.5: If we deal with one another for these offenses, this legal issue might lead to harshness, nastiness, and schism.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.6: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should resolve this legal issue by covering over as if with grass, except for heavy offenses and offenses connected with householders.’
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.7: The monks belonging to one side should then be informed by a competent and capable monk belonging to their own side:
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.8: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask you to listen.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.9: While we were arguing and disputing, we did and said many things unworthy of monastics.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.10: If we deal with one another for these offenses, this legal issue might lead to harshness, nastiness, and schism.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.11: If it seems appropriate to you, then for your benefit and for my own, I’ll confess in the midst of the Sangha both your and my own offenses by covering over as if with grass, except for heavy offenses and offenses connected with householders.’
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.12: And the monks belonging to the other side should be informed by a competent and capable monk belonging to their own side:
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.13: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask you to listen.
pli-tv-kd14:13.2.14: While we were arguing and disputing, we did and said many things unworthy of monastics.

pli-tv-kd14:14.1.1: On one occasion monks were disputing with monks, monks with nuns, and nuns with monks. Standing with the nuns, the monk Channa disputed with the monks, making others side with the nuns.

pli-tv-kd14:14.1.8: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.1: “Monks, there are four kinds of legal issues: legal issues arising from disputes; legal issues arising from accusations; legal issues arising from offenses; legal issues arising from business.
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.2: (1a) What’s a legal issue arising from a dispute?
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.3: It may be that the monks are disputing, saying,
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.4: ‘This is the Teaching’, ‘This is contrary to the Teaching’, ‘This is the Monastic Law’, ‘This is contrary to the Monastic Law’, ‘This was spoken by the Buddha’, ‘This wasn’t spoken by the Buddha’, ‘This was practiced by the Buddha’, ‘This wasn’t practiced by the Buddha’, ‘This was laid down by the Buddha’, ‘This wasn’t laid down by the Buddha’, ‘This is an offense’, ‘This isn’t an offense’, ‘This is a light offense’, ‘This is a heavy offense’, ‘This is a curable offense’, ‘This is an incurable offense’, ‘This is a grave offense’, or ‘This is a minor offense.’
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.5: In regard to this, whatever there is of quarreling, arguing, conflict, disputing, variety in opinion, difference in opinion, heated speech, or strife—
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.6: this is called a legal issue arising from a dispute.
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.7: (1b) What’s a legal issue arising from an accusation?
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.8: It may be that the monks accuse a monk of failure in morality, failure in conduct, failure in view, or failure in livelihood.
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.9: In regard to this, whatever there is of accusations, accusing, allegations, blame, taking sides because of friendship, taking part in the accusation, or supporting the accusation—
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.10: this is called a legal issue arising from an accusation.
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.11: (1c) What’s a legal issue arising from an offense?
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.12: There are legal issues arising from offenses because of the five classes of offenses; there are legal issues arising from offenses because of the seven classes of offenses—
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.13: this is called a legal issue arising from an offense.
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.14: (1d) What’s a legal issue arising from business?
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.15: Whatever is the duty or the business of the Sangha—a legal procedure consisting of getting permission, a legal procedure consisting of one motion, a legal procedure consisting of one motion and one announcement, a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements—
pli-tv-kd14:14.2.16: this is called a legal issue arising from business.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.1: (2a) What’s the root of legal issues arising from disputes?
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.2: There are six roots of disputes that in turn are the root of legal issues arising from disputes.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.3: There are also three unwholesome and three wholesome roots of legal issues arising from disputes.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.4: What are the six roots of disputes that in turn are the root of legal issues arising from disputes?
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.5: It may be that a monk is angry and resentful.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.6: One who’s angry and resentful is disrespectful and undeferential toward the Teacher, the Teaching, and the Sangha, and he doesn’t fulfill the training.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.10: Disputes are unbeneficial and a cause of unhappiness for humanity; they’re harmful, detrimental, and a cause of suffering for gods and humans.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.11: Monks, when you see such a root of disputes either in yourself or others, you should make an effort to get rid of it.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.12: If you don’t see such a root either in yourself or others, you should practice so that it doesn’t emerge in the future.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.13: In this way that bad root of disputes is abandoned
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.14: and doesn’t emerge in the future.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.15: Or it may be that a monk is denigrating and controlling,
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.16: envious and stingy, treacherous and deceitful, one who has bad desires and wrong views, or one who obstinately grasps his own views and only gives them up with difficulty.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.17: Such a monk is disrespectful and undeferential toward the Teacher, the Teaching, and the Sangha, and he doesn’t fulfill the training.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.21: Disputes are unbeneficial and a cause of unhappiness for humanity; they’re harmful, detrimental, and a cause of suffering for gods and humans.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.22: Monks, when you see such a root of disputes either in yourself or others, you should make an effort to get rid of it.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.23: If you don’t see such a root either in yourself or others, you should practice so that it doesn’t emerge in the future.
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.24: In this way that bad root of disputes is abandoned
pli-tv-kd14:14.3.25: and doesn’t emerge in the future.
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.1: What are the three unwholesome roots of legal issues arising from disputes?
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.2: It may be that monks dispute with a mind of greed, ill will, or delusion, saying,
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.3: ‘This is the Teaching’, ‘This is contrary to the Teaching’, ‘This is the Monastic Law’, ‘This is contrary to the Monastic Law’, ‘This was spoken by the Buddha’, ‘This wasn’t spoken by the Buddha’, ‘This was practiced by the Buddha’, ‘This wasn’t practiced by the Buddha’, ‘This was laid down by the Buddha’, ‘This wasn’t laid down by the Buddha’, ‘This is an offense’, ‘This isn’t an offense’, ‘This is a light offense’, ‘This is a heavy offense’, ‘This is a curable offense’, ‘This is an incurable offense’, ‘This is a grave offense’, or ‘This is a minor offense.’
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.5: What are the three wholesome roots of legal issues arising from disputes?
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.6: It may be that monks dispute with a mind free from greed, ill will, and delusion, saying,
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.7: ‘This is the Teaching’, ‘This is contrary to the Teaching’ …
pli-tv-kd14:14.4.8: ‘This is a grave offense’, or ‘This is a minor offense.’
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.1: (2b) What’s the root of legal issues arising from accusations?
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.2: There are six roots of accusations that in turn are the root of legal issues arising from accusations.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.3: There are also three unwholesome and three wholesome roots of legal issues arising from accusations. The body, too, is a root of legal issues arising from accusations, as is speech.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.4: What are the six roots of accusations that in turn are the root of legal issues arising from accusations?
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.5: It may be that a monk is angry and resentful.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.6: One who is angry and resentful is disrespectful and undeferential toward the Teacher, the Teaching, and the Sangha, and he doesn’t fulfill the training.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.10: Accusations are unbeneficial and a cause of unhappiness for humanity; they’re harmful, detrimental, and a cause of suffering for gods and humans.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.11: Monks, when you see such a root of accusations either in yourself or others, you should make an effort to get rid of it.

pli-tv-kd14:14.5.22: Monks, when you see such a root of accusations either in yourself or others, you should make an effort to get rid of it.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.23: If you don’t see such a root either in yourself or others, you should practice so that it doesn’t emerge in the future.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.27: What are the three unwholesome roots of accusations?
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.28: It may be that monks, because of greed, ill will, or delusion, accuse a monk of
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.29: failure in morality, conduct, view, or livelihood.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.31: What are the three wholesome roots of accusations?
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.32: It may be that monks, because of non-greed, non-ill will, and non-delusion, accuse a monk of
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.33: failure in morality, conduct, view, or livelihood.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.35: How’s the body a root of legal issues arising from accusations?
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.36: It may be that someone is ugly, unsightly, a dwarf, sickly, blind in one eye, crooked-limbed, lame, or paralyzed, and they blame him for that.
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.38: How’s speech a root of legal issues arising from accusations?
pli-tv-kd14:14.5.39: It may be that someone is difficult to correct, or he stutters or dribbles while speaking, and they blame him for that.
pli-tv-kd14:14.6.1: (2c) What’s the root of legal issues arising from offenses?
pli-tv-kd14:14.6.2: There are six origins of offenses that in turn are the root of legal issues arising from offenses.
pli-tv-kd14:14.6.3: There are offenses that originate from the body, but not from speech or the mind.

pli-tv-kd14:14.6.8: There are offenses that originate from the body, speech, and the mind.

pli-tv-kd14:14.7.2: There’s one root of legal issues arising from business:
pli-tv-kd14:14.8.1: (3a) Is a legal issue arising from a dispute wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate?
pli-tv-kd14:14.8.2: A legal issue arising from a dispute may be wholesome, unwholesome, or indeterminate.

pli-tv-kd14:14.8.19: In regard to this, whatever there is of quarreling, arguing, conflict, disputing, variety in opinion, difference in opinion, heated speech, or strife—

pli-tv-kd14:14.13.15: A legal issue arising from an accusation is a legal issue and also an accusation.

pli-tv-kd14:14.14.12: How’s there a legal issue that’s also an offense?
pli-tv-kd14:14.14.13: A legal issue arising from an offense is a legal issue and also an offense.

pli-tv-kd14:14.15.12: How’s there a legal issue that’s also business?

pli-tv-kd14:14.33.43: This is called the resolution of a legal issue.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.45: It’s been resolved face-to-face and by covering over as if with grass.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.47: Face-to-face with the Sangha, the Teaching, the Monastic Law, and the persons concerned.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.48: This is the meaning of face-to-face with the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.49: the monks who should be present have arrived, consent has been brought for those who are eligible to give their consent, and no one present objects to the decision.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.51: This is the meaning of face-to-face with the Teaching and the Monastic Law:
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.52: the Teaching, the Monastic Law, the Teacher’s instruction—that by which that legal issue is resolved.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.54: This is the meaning of face-to-face with the persons concerned:
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.55: both the one who confesses and the one he confesses to are present.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.57: This is the meaning of covering over as if with grass:
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.58: the doing of, the performing of, the participation in, the consent to, the agreement to, the non-objection to that legal procedure of covering over as if with grass.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.60: When a legal issue has been resolved like this, if a receiver of the confession reopens it, he incurs an offense entailing confession for the reopening.
pli-tv-kd14:14.33.61: If anyone who gave their consent criticizes the resolution, they incur an offense entailing confession.
